title: Denny Solomona
text:
Denny Solomona (born 27 September 1993) is a <a href="rugby%20football">rugby football</a>er who plays <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> as a <a href="Wing%20%28rugby%20union%29">winger</a> for the <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a> at international level. He previously played rugby union for <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> in <a href="Premiership%20Rugby">Premiership Rugby</a> and played <a href="rugby%20league">rugby league</a> as a winger for the <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a> Under-20s, <a href="London%20Broncos">London Broncos</a> and the <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford Tigers</a> (<a href="List%20of%20Castleford%20Tigers%20players">Heritage № 951</a>). He played for <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a> at international rugby league.
Youth.
Solomona was born and brought up in <a href="Auckland">Auckland</a>, and was educated at <a href="St%20Peter%27s%20College%2C%20Auckland">St Peter's College</a> where he was a member of the school's Rugby Union First XV and won the Boris Shroj Cup in 2010 as the top try scorer.
Rugby League.
In 2012, Solomona became a member of the <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a> Rugby League franchise being recruited out of Melbourne's youth system. He only played 13 games during the 2012 <a href="National%20Youth%20Competition%20%28rugby%20league%29">National Youth Competition</a> season, with a fractured <a href="fibula">fibula</a> in Round 13. Nevertheless, the 19-year-old scored eight tries from those 13 games. Solomona joined the Melbourne Storm's senior squad in <a href="2013%20Melbourne%20Storm%20season">2013</a>.
Solomona signed for <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> side <a href="London%20Broncos">London Broncos</a> in January 2014 after being released from his contract with <a href="Melbourne%20Storm">Melbourne Storm</a>. Following the club's relegation, it was announced that he would join <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford Tigers</a> at the end of the season.
In 2016, Solomona scored a record-breaking 37th try in a single <a href="Super%20League">Super League</a> season in Castleford's Super 8s win over Catalans. The try broke a 12-year record held by former dual-international, <a href="Lesley%20Vainikolo">Lesley Vainikolo</a>. Solomona finished the season with a total of 40 tries along with another 2 in the <a href="Challenge%20Cup">Challenge Cup</a> competition. On 8 October 2016 Solomona made his International début for <a href="Samoa%20national%20rugby%20league%20team">Samoa</a> in their historical <a href="2016%20Samoa%20vs.%20Fiji%20rugby%20league%20test%20match">test match</a> against Fiji in Apia.
Rugby Union.
On 13 December 2016, it was confirmed that Solomona had retired from rugby league, with two years still remaining on his contract with <a href="Castleford%20Tigers">Castleford Tigers</a>, to switch to <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a>, and join <a href="Sale%20Sharks">Sale Sharks</a> in the <a href="English%20Premiership%20%28rugby%20union%29">Aviva Premiership</a>. The move was subject to a legal dispute which was concluded out of court as Sale paid Castleford some £200,000 in compensation. On 29 March 2017, having enjoyed a prolific start to his career with Sale (10 tries in 11 appearances), Solomona declared himself available for international selection with <a href="England%20national%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>. He was subsequently called up to the senior England squad by <a href="Eddie%20Jones%20%28rugby%20union%29">Eddie Jones</a> for their 2017 summer tour of Argentina and came on as a sub in the opening test and scored the winning try on his debut.l
Influences.
Solomona feels that meeting senior players can be important for the motivation and development of school age players.
